adjective.description: Moving or operating, or designed to do so, only at a low speed; not quick or fast.
examples: a time when diesel cars were slow and noisy

adjective.description: (of a clock or watch) showing a time earlier than the correct time.
examples: the clock was five minutes slow

adjective.description: Not prompt to understand, think, or learn.

examples: a slow and mostly aimless narrative

adjective.description: (of a fire or oven) burning or giving off heat gently.
examples: bake the dish in a preheated slow oven
the train went slower and slower

verb.description: Reduce one's speed or the speed of a vehicle or process.
examples: the train slowed to a halt

phrases: a slow but sure increase in the price of gold
I chose a stately breaststroke, slow but sure, that meant I could keep an eye on our target.
This drug started to run its course slow but sure.
Brian took the animal home and the recovery has been slow but sure.
Hearing nothing they continued on, their steps slow and sure, not making a sound.
origin: Old English slāw slow-witted, sluggish, of Germanic origin.
